dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Afterpay's valuation just doubled to two billion dollars since 2018.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they're not the only ones—Affirm's rumored to be planning a billion-dollar IPO too.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and now Square's jumping in with their Pay in 4 product for items between $100 and $700.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its new Pay in 4 product will let you pay for any items that cost between $30 and $600 in four installments over six weeks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: What's interesting is how different the fee structures are. Afterpay charges retailers about 2%, but no late fees for consumers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: What's interesting is how different the fee structures are. Afterpay charges retailers about two percent, but no late fees for consumers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Afterpay charges retailers roughly 5% of each transaction to offer its financing feature. It doesnt charge interest to the consumer, but if youre late on a payment, youll pay fees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Affirm's got that 10% retailer fee, plus late fees sometimes, but usually no interest.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Affirm's got that ten percent retailer fee, plus late fees sometimes, but usually no interest.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But most of the time, it makes users pay interest of 10 - 30%, and it has no late fees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Then there's PayPal, which seems like a hybrid—interest for consumers, fees for retailers, and late fees up to a dollar.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Then there's PayPal, which seems like a hybrid-interest for consumers, fees for retailers, and late fees up to a dollar.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It wont charge interest to the consumer or an additional fee to the retailer, but if youre late on a payment, youll pay a fee of up to $10.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and PayPal's got this huge network advantage. Twenty percent of top U.S. retailers already accept it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and PayPal's got this huge network advantage. Twenty percent of top U.S. retailers already accept it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Eighty percent of the top 100 retailers in the U.S. let customers pay with PayPal, and nearly 70% of U.S. online buyers have PayPal accounts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which probably helps them undercut others on fees. They only charge retailers 0.9% plus ten cents per transaction.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which probably helps them undercut others on fees. They only charge retailers zero point nine percent plus ten cents per transaction.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: PayPal charges retailers per-transaction fees of 2.9% plus $0.30, and in the second quarter, as Covid-19 made online purchases skyrocket, it saw record revenues of $5.3 billion and profits of $1.5 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And they had record revenues last quarter—$1.3 billion, even with the stock shrinking.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But here's the thing—data shows people actually spend less when they use point-of-sale financing, like 5% less sometimes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But here's the thing-data shows people actually spend less when they use point-of-sale financing, like five percent less sometimes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Data from Afterpay and PayPal show that consumers spend more moneysometimes 20% morewhen theyre offered point of sale financing options.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So when Square launches Pay in 4, their transaction sizes might drop, and so will their fee revenue.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So when Square launches Pay in four, their transaction sizes might drop, and so will their fee revenue.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When PayPal launches Pay in 4 this fall, it will likely see transaction sizes rise, and since it already earns 2.9% on each transaction, its fee revenue will rise in tandem.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they're putting these loans on their own balance sheet, which apparently makes them uncomfortable from a risk perspective.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they're putting these loans on their own balance sheet, which apparently makes them uncomfortable from a risk perspective.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Unlike PayPal Credit, PayPal will house these new loans on its own balance sheet. Bland says, Were incredibly comfortable in managing the credit risk of this.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Unlike PayPal Credit, which has been around longer and has tens of borrowers now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unlike PayPal Credit, which has been around longer and has tens of borrowers now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: PayPal Credit lets consumers apply for a lump-sum line of credit and has millions of borrowers today.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild how these companies are pushing into lending even when consumer defaults are a risk.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild how these companies are pushing into lending even when consumer defaults are a risk.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Especially in an economy where, uh, a lot of people aren't doing so well.

artist_script:
HostA: Afterpay's valuation just doubled to two billion dollars since 2018.
HostB: Yeah, and they’re not the only ones—Affirm’s rumored to be planning a billion-dollar IPO too.
HostA: Right, and now Square’s jumping in with their Pay in 4 product for items between $100 and $700.
HostB: What’s interesting is how different the fee structures are. Afterpay charges retailers about 2%, but no late fees for consumers.
HostA: And Affirm’s got that 10% retailer fee, plus late fees sometimes, but usually no interest.
HostB: Then there’s PayPal, which seems like a hybrid—interest for consumers, fees for retailers, and late fees up to a dollar.
HostA: Yeah, and PayPal’s got this huge network advantage. Twenty percent of top U.S. retailers already accept it.
HostB: Which probably helps them undercut others on fees. They only charge retailers 0.9% plus ten cents per transaction.
HostA: And they had record revenues last quarter—$1.3 billion, even with the stock shrinking.
HostB: But here’s the thing—data shows people actually spend less when they use point-of-sale financing, like 5% less sometimes.
HostA: So when Square launches Pay in 4, their transaction sizes might drop, and so will their fee revenue.
HostB: And they’re putting these loans on their own balance sheet, which apparently makes them uncomfortable from a risk perspective.
HostA: Unlike PayPal Credit, which has been around longer and has tens of borrowers now.
HostB: It’s wild how these companies are pushing into lending even when consumer defaults are a risk.
HostA: Especially in an economy where, uh, a lot of people aren’t doing so well.
